abstract.text: Sends a Read Single Block command (0x20 command code), as defined in the ISO 15693-3 specification, to the tag.

inlineContent.text: The request flags. The
flag is enforced by default. However, using the
flag disables the
flag.
The number of the block to read. Blocks are numbered from 0 to 255 inclusively.
A handler that the reader session invokes after the operation completes. The session calls completionHandler on the dispatch queue that you provided when creating the NFCTagReaderSession object.
The handler has the following parameters:
A
object containing the blocks of data read from the tag. If the request flags include
, the first byte of the data contains the associated block security status.
data
when the operation is successful; otherwise, an
object indicating that a problem occurred while communicating with the tag.
error
When the tag responds with a command error, the error’s
directory contains the
and the error’s
property has a value defined in the ISO15693-3 specification.

with the command.

abstract.text: Detect NFC tags, read messages that contain NDEF data, and save data to writable tags.
A bit mask value that turns on the address flag.
A bit mask value that turns on the option flag.
A bit mask value that turns on the select flag.
An interface for interacting with an ISO 15693 tag.
The unique hardware identifier of the tag.
Sends the Lock Block command (0x22 command code), as defined in the ISO 15693-3 specification, to the tag.
Sends a Read Single Block command (0x20 command code), as defined in the ISO 15693-3 specification, to the tag.
Sends the Write Single Block command (0x21 command code), as defined in the ISO 15693-3 specification, to the tag.
A user information dictionary key indicating that a tag responded with a command error.
A static byte buffer that bridges to ; use  when you need reference semantics or other Foundation-specific behavior.
Information about an error condition including a domain, a domain-specific error code, and application-specific information.
The error code.
The user info dictionary.
A static byte buffer that bridges to ; use  when you need reference semantics or other Foundation-specific behavior.
Information about an error condition including a domain, a domain-specific error code, and application-specific information.
A byte buffer in memory.
The return type of functions that don’t explicitly specify a return type, that is, an empty tuple `()`.
A type representing an error value that can be thrown.
An 8-bit unsigned integer value type.
